intro: Dimorphanthera amblyornidis var. moorhousiana, commonly known as the Moorhouse's dimorphanthera, is a rare and endemic flowering plant native to the humid forests of northern Queensland, Australia. It is characterized by its delicate, pale green foliage and small, clustered white flowers that bloom during the cooler months. The plant typically grows as a low shrub, reaching heights of up to 30 centimeters, with a compact and bushy habit. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a waxy texture, which helps it retain moisture in its native environment. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is considered a vulnerable species and is often found in protected conservation areas.
